text:
JAMES REINHART: The
average American

doesn't wear 70% of the
clothes in their closet.

The reality is that there's
too much clothing in the world.

Most of the stuff that people
donate ends up in a landfill.

So we'd like to believe that
everything we're giving away

is being reused, but the reality
is a lot of that stuff is not.

Our mission at
thredUP was really

to inspire a new generation
to think secondhand first.

How could we figure out a
way to help people clean out

their closets and
make some money

and then figure out
a way for buyers

to buy incredibly high-quality
secondhand clothing?

Operations is at the core
of everything that we do.

We run the two largest
garment on hangar facilities
in the world.

We'll process our 100 millionth
piece of clothing this year.

Every day we're processing
more than 100,000 unique items.

And so we've built
a big business

on the back of an incredible
logistics and supply chain.

I think the thing that drives
me as an entrepreneur is

seeing the ability to make
an impact on a person's life.

When I started my career,
it was I was a teacher.

And it was about kids and
it was about families.

And so I think having a company
where day in and day out I

can get positive feedback
that I helped the customer buy

a dress that they would never
have been able to afford

or a kid have a perfect first
day school outfit for less,

I think those are the small
things that really drive me
as the founder.

And I think those
are the things that
drive us as an organization.

I never thought that we would be
in a position to really change
the way retail works.

Creating a circular economy in
apparel that previously had not

existed, that's been the most
rewarding part of the journey.
I'm an eternal optimist.

I believe that the
sun will always

come out, that business will
always be better the next day.
Going to work.

Working hard, I think all
those things pay off over time.

You can't always see it when
you're right in the moment,

but when you zoom out,
what's a good life?

It's a collection of
a bunch of good days.
